occurrences.line_text: Bold Marinell of Britomart,
Of bold Penthesilee, which made a lake
How can they other do, sith both are bold and blind?
By your good counsell, or bold hardiment,
And bold, as euer Squire that waited by knights side.
Which he had borne of his bold enimee.
From a bold knight, that with great hardinesse
But that bold knight, whom ye pursuing saw
Approching, with bold words and bitter threat,
Her to recomfort, and accourage bold,
But that old leachour, which with bold assault
Who through great prowesse and bold hardinesse,
For noble Britons sprong from Troians bold,
Subdewd with losse of many Britons bold:
That bold he said; ï¿½ most redoubted Pere,
Which the bold Virgin seeing, gan apply
There they dismounting, drew their weapons bold
Who bold to guide the charet of the Sunne,
Be bold: she oft and oft it ouer-red,
But forward with bold steps into the next roome went.
Be bold, be bold, and euery where Be bold,
Be bold, be bold, and euery where Be bold,
Be bold, be bold, and euery where Be bold,
Be not too bold; whereto though she did bend
Yet the bold Britonesse was nought ydred,
Bold Britomart, as she had late forecast,
It was to weete the bold Sir Ferraugh hight,
So fortune friends the bold: whom Paridell
Bold was the chalenge, as himselfe was bold,
Bold was the chalenge, as himselfe was bold,
Amongst those knights there were three brethren bold,
Got these three louely babes, that prov'd three cha[m]pions bold.
To whom fierce Atropos, Bold Fay, that durst
Then tooke the bold Sir Satyrane in hand
Hight Bruncheual the bold, who fiersly forth did ride.
The wrathfull weapon gainst his countnance bold:
Ne euer Knight so bold, ne euer Dame
The traines of wit, in wickednesse woxe bold,
I boldly thought (so young mens thoughts are bold)
And with the terrour of his countenance bold
In greater perils to be stout and bold,
And sharpe rebuke, for being ouer bold;
And mightie Albion, father of the bold
That her all Greece with many a champion bold
And valiant hearts, in thoughts lesse hard and bold,
Bold Marinell with Florimell the fayre,
Is for the sake of Bellodant the bold,
Vnknowen perill of bold womens pride.
Bold Radigund with sound of trumpe on hight,
Say on my souerayne Ladie, and be bold;
Till she againe thus sayd; Talus be bold,
Had long surceast, she bad to open bold,
So faire a creature, and so wondrous bold,
A bold defyance, did of him requere
But the bold child that perill well espying,
As this bold woman, when she saw that Damzell there.
To weet a wicked villaine, bold and stout,
Both with bold speaches, which he blazed had,
For the bold title of a Poet bad
Did beare the pendants, through their nimblesse bold:
Then this bold Tyrant, of her widowhed
He stepped forth with courage bold and great,
And with bold vaunts, and ydle threatning bad
That the bold Prince was forced foote to giue
Them also gan assaile with outrage bold,
Why hath thy hand too bold it selfe embrewed
Being oppressed by that faytour bold,
But the bold knight no whit thereat dismayd,
The wife of bold Sir Bruin, who is Lord
Or gard her to defend from bold oppressors might.
For well they wist, that Squire to be so bold,
But he, the more outrageous and bold,
But the bold Prince defended him so well,
Not that the burden of so bold a guest
When the bold Centaures made that bloudy fray
Fell all at ods, and fought through fury fierce and bold.
Vnto the entrance ran: where the bold knight
Fiercely they followd on their bolde emprize,
Three bolder brethren neuer were yborne,
The most vnruly, and the boldest boy,
And with his trenchand blade her boldly kept
The Sprite then gan more boldly him to wake,
With fowle reprochfull words he boldly him defide.
Then gin the blustring brethren boldly threat,
For may I boldly say, he surely is
Their sharpe assault right boldly did rebut,
So boldly he him beares, and rusheth forth
But when I other knew, my selfe I boldly reard.
He boldly spake, Sir knight, if knight thou bee,
Him boldly bad his passage there to stay,
The thing it selfe. In hand she boldly tooke
His bloudie speare eftsoones he boldly bent
They after both, and boldly bad him bace,
He made him open chalenge, and thus boldly sayd.
To which I boldly came vpon my feeble feete.
Who thrusting boldly twixt him and the blow,
I boldly thought (so young mens thoughts are bold)
Whom boldly I encountred (as I could)
He boldly aunswerd him, he there did stand
Declare it boldly Dame, and doe not stand in dout.
Yet boldly answer'd, as he rightly might;
There he arriuing boldly, did present
And entraunce boldly vnto him forbad.
That durst so boldly, without let or shame,
Boldly him bad such iniurie forbeare;
But through his boldnesse rather feare did reach,
Yet feared least his boldnesse should offend,
The knight at his great boldnesse wondered,
He from such hardy boldnesse was restraind,
Pardon the boldnesse of thy basest thrall,
And they that most in boldnesse doe excell,
Vnder his club with wary boldnesse went,
That through she passed; as a thunder bolt
BON FONT: but bon that once had written bin,
BON FONT: but bon that once had written bin,
Vpon a great aduenture he was bond,
Therefore since mine he is, or free or bond,
His sunbroad shield about his wrest he bond,
And Guyons shield about his wrest he bond;
Good turnes be counted, as a seruile bond,
Are bound with commun bond of frailtee,
With Canacee and Cambine linckt in louely bond.
Cambina with true friendships bond
And eke his caue, in which they both were bond:
Left in the victors powre, like vassall bond;
To doe her seruice, so as I am bond.
Enlincked fast in wedlockes loyall bond,
But he had brought it now in seruile bond,
Till his returne vnto this tree he bond:
From whose eternall bondage now they were releast.
Vpon the parts, brought into their bondage:
Where in eternall bondage dye he must,
To view the thrals, which there in bondage lay:
All which he did from bitter bondage free,
Whose scalp is bare, that bondage doth bewray,
In her false hart, his bondage to vnbind;
In womans bondage, Talus to her brought;
In wretched bondage, wofully bestad.
Thy maisters shame, in harlots bondage tide.
And bring in bondage of their brutishnesse:
To merchants, which them kept in bondage hard,
Amongst those theeues, which her in bondage strong
To see him leade that Beast in bondage strong,
To skim those coastes, for bondmen there to buy,
And passe the bonds of modest merimake,
Her angrie teame breaking their bonds of peace,
To breake all bonds of law, and rules of right.
Till Fortune would her captiue bonds vnbynde:
But vanquisht thine eternall bondslaue make,
Arriu'd in place, their bondslaues for to buy;
Each bone might through his body well be red,
To plucke a bone, then from his cruell claw
And bared all his head vnto the bone;
And eke through feare as white as whales bone:
Of earthly mould, and form'd of flesh and bone,
Vnto the bone, and made a griesly wound,
Those he deuoures, they say, both flesh and bone:
Being vnable to digest that bone;
Dead sculs & bones of men, whose life had gone astray.
And dead mens bones, which round about were flong,
And through her bones the false instilled fire
In which old Styx her aged bones alway,
His cheeke bones raw, and eie-pits hollow grew,
His timbered bones all broken rudely rumbled:
Her brothers bones she scattered all about;
That all his bones, as small as sandy grayle
And all her bones might through her cheekes be red;
That all his bones in peeces nigh he brake.
And his embrodered Bonet sat awry;
Finis Book II.
And by his belt his booke he hanging had;
A booke, wherein his Saueours testament
Their times in his eternall booke of fate
A booke, that was both signd and seald with blood,
And that her sacred Booke, with bloud ywrit,
That couet in th'immortall booke of fame
An auncient booke, hight Briton moniments,
Sir Guyon chaunst eke on another booke,
As in that old mans booke they were in order told.
But Guyon all this while his booke did read,
Vnfitly furnisht with thy bag and booke,
Full dreadfull things out of that balefull booke
[here, in 1609, 'The end of the Fourth Booke.']
Her vomit full of bookes and papers was,
His Magick bookes and artes of sundry kindes,
He cast about, and searcht his balefull bookes againe.
And fortunes tell, and read in louing bookes,
To read those bookes; who gladly graunted their desire.
So halfe vnwilling from their bookes them brought,
As it in bookes hath written bene of old.
As it in antique bookes is mentioned.
His wicked bookes in hast he ouerthrew,
Begot of foule Echidna, as in bookes is taught.
Some made in books, some in long parchme[n]t scrolles,
For which to God he made so many an idle boone.
To graunt her boone, and rigour to abate,
And meekest boone, that they imagine mought.
With his sad guide; himselfe she tooke a boord,
By faire Kilkenny and Rosseponte boord,
Ere long with like againe he boorded mee,
Patience perforce; helpelesse what may it boot
To better boot, but let me dye, that ought;
With hope of her some wishfull boot to haue.
That naught may boot to banishe them from thence:
It could not boot, needs mote she die at last:
It booted nought, to thinke, such thunderbolts to beare.
It booted nought to thinke, to robbe him of his pray.
It booted nought Sir Guyon comming neare
Nought booted it the Paynim then to striue;
It booted not to thinke that throw to beare,
At last when sorrow he saw booted nought,
From which to thinke to saue himselfe, it booted not.
Him booted not to thinke them to pursew,
Which booted nought for prayers, nor for threat
Their bootelesse paines, and ill succeeding night:
His bootelesse bow in feeble hand vpcaught,
Who when he saw it bootelesse to resist,
For bootelesse thing him seemed, to abide
For what bootes it to weepe and to wayment,
What bootes it all to haue, and nothing vse?
What bootes it him from death to be vnbound,
But foolish boy, what bootes thy seruice bace
For little bootes against him hand to reare.
But all bootes not: they hands vpon her lay;
Him booteth not resist, nor succour call,
From whom her booteth not at all to flie;
And helplesse hap it booteth not to mone.
What booteth then the good and righteous deed,
That where they bite, it booteth not to weene
Of that faire bootie, and with bitter wracke
Where is the bootie, which therefore I bought,
But leauing watry gods, as booting nought,
And with sharpe shrilling shriekes doe bootlesse cry,
But when their bootlesse zeale she did restraine
That scarsely could he weeld his bootlesse single blade.
Vaine was the watch, and bootlesse all the ward,
For bootlesse thing it was to think such blowes to beare.
Euen so did Radigund with bootlesse paine
O what of Gods then boots it to be borne,
What boots it boast thy glorious descent,
What boots it plaine, that cannot be redrest,
What boots it then to plaine, that cannot be redrest?
To seeke for booty, came by fortune blynde,
But fed on spoile and booty, which they made
Whom thus at gaze, the Palmer gan to bord
He loudly cald to such, as were a bord,
Till him the Prince with gentle court did bord;
Of British bloud, all sitting at his bord;
Them gan to bord, and purpose diuersly,
The wisard could no lenger beare her bord,
When so in open place, and commune bord,
And she receiu'd againe to bed and bord,
Was closed vp, as it had not bene bor'd,
And pleasaunt bord, they past forth on their way,
Who sitting with his Lady then at bord,
Yet making many a borde, and many a bay,
Which from Alcluid to Panwelt did that border bound.
And round about a border was entrayld,
Like to a golden border did appeare,
And straungers to deuoure, which on their border
Vpon their neighbours, which did nigh them border,
That round about was bordered with a wood
Vnto the Prince of Picteland bordering nere,
Through both whose borders swiftly downe it glides,
Into their neighbours borders; ne did giue
Yet oft annoyd with sundry bordragings
Whose skirts were bordred with bright sunny beams,
But on his brest a bloudie Crosse he bore,
And on his litle winges the dreame he bore
That on her shoulders sad a pot of water bore.
That wont in charet chace the foming Bore;
And bore a boy vnto that saluage sire:
The spotted Panther, and the tusked Bore,
Which still she bore, replete with magick artes;
That huge great body, which the Gyaunt bore,
And on his arme a bounch of keyes he bore,
And in her right hand bore a cup of gold,
As chauffed Bore his bristles doth vpreare,
Long he them bore aboue the subiect plaine,
But now they laurell braunches bore in hand;
Deare Sonne, great beene the euils, which ye bore
He bore a bloudie Crosse, that quartred all the field.
Behind his backe he bore a brasen shield,
The trees did bud, and earely blossomes bore,
Of loue they euer greater glory bore,
Whose squire bore after him an heben launce,
Then for her sonne, which she to Locrin bore,
Vpon his shield their heaped hayle he bore,
How th'Earth his mother was, and first him bore;
First through the Euxine seas bore all the flowr of Greece.
Of Rhodope, on which the Nimphe, that bore
That bore a Lion passant in a golden field.
Nathelesse it bore his foe not from his sell,
For neuer yet, sith warlike armes he bore,
Ah gentlest knight, that euer armour bore,
And in his clownish hand a sharp bore speare he shooke.
Deadly engored of a great wild Bore,
Of which they still the girlond bore away,
He bore a crowned litle Ermilin,
But him perforce vnto the ground it bore:
Him so transfixed she before her bore
She bore Belphoebe, she bore in like cace
She bore Belphoebe, she bore in like cace
Vnwares she them conceiu'd, vnwares she bore:
She bore withouten paine, that she conceiued
For that wilde Bore, the which him once annoyd,
And in his Scutchin bore a Satyres hed:
She bore before her lap a dolefull Squire,
She bore him fast away. Which when the knight,
For at that berth another Babe she bore,
But Florimell with him vnto his bowre he bore.
With speaking lookes, that close embassage bore,
And of all Asie bore the soueraigne crowne,
And greedy eares her weake hart from her bore:
Yet bore so faire a saile, that none espyde
Through open outrage he her bore away,
That in his hand a branch of laurell bore,
Which first it opened; and bore all away.
That bore great sway in armes and chiualrie,
To be Sir Scudamour, by that he bore
The whiles his loue away the other bore,
That bore three such, three such not to be fond;
In her right hand a rod of peace shee bore,
For euill deedes may better then bad words be bore.
His speare he feutred, and at him it bore;
Which else was like to haue bene lost, and bore
That bore the Hebene speare, as wonne in fight.
But secretly from thence that night her bore away.
So likewise did the hammers which they bore,
The armes he bore, his speare he gan abase,
And with the force, which in it selfe it bore,
With huge great teeth, like to a tusked Bore:
And in his hand a tall young oake he bore,
And through the forrest bore her quite away,
Whilest he in armes her bore; but when she felt
Ne was there man so strong, but he downe bore,
I lightly snatcht him vp, and with me bore away.
That all the while he by his side her bore,
And in them bore true louers vowes entire:
That euen yet the Dolphin, which him bore
And auncient heauy burden, which he bore
For that same golden fleecy Ram, which bore
And shouldred hath the Bull, which fayre Europa bore.
And as I marked, bore vpon his shield,
Ne any Knight was absent, that braue courage bore.
And all these knights, which that day armour bore,
Which bore the Sunne brode blazed in a golden field.
Both brethren, whom one wombe together bore,
To whom she bore most feruent loue of late,
Yet still her blowes he bore, and her forbore,
Vppon her speare she bore before her breast,
And bore him quite out of his saddle, longer
By some bad spirit, that it to mischiefe bore,
She forth did rome, whether her rage her bore,
Als at his backe a great wyde net he bore,
Who with a cloud of night him couering, bore
The same longwhile I bore, and therewithall
So bore her quite away, nor well nor ill apayd.
The heauy Mayd, to whom none tydings bore
The Dwarfe, which bore that message to her knight,
Whom on his backe he bore, till he him brought
A cruell Beare, the which an infant bore
She bore it thence, and euer as her owne it kept.
Yet he himselfe so well and wisely bore,
And in all battels bore away the baies.
Ne euer Knight, that bore so lofty creast,
His vitall breath, and to the ground him bore,
And in his hand a mighty yron club he bore.
And with his yron batton, which he bore,
That Theseus her vnto his bridale bore,
And eeke them selues so in their daunce they bore,
And robd of reason, towards her him bore,
So droue them all away, and his loue with him bore.
So home vnto his honest wife it bore,
The which she bore, the whiles in prison she did dwell.
Straunge bands, whose like till then he neuer bore,
Where Boreas doth blow full bitter bleake,
As when the wrathfull Boreas doth bluster,
As when two Bores with rancling malice met,
Some like wild Bores late rouzd out of the brakes;
And in her hand a sharpe bore-speare she held,
And still the foster with his long bore-speare
And in his left he held a sharpe borespeare,
And said, Faire knight, borne vnder happy starre,
And that new creature borne without her dew,
For him so far had borne his light-foot steede,
Borne the sole daughter of an Emperour,
And twixt them both was borne the bloudy bold Sans loy.
Arose the virgin borne of heauenly brood,
And false Duessa in her sted had borne,
Haue borne him hence to Plutoes balefull bowres.
O what of Gods then boots it to be borne,
The fall of famous children borne of mee,
In doubt to deeme her borne of earthly brood;
For ransome leauing him the late borne childe;
Is not short paine well borne, that brings long ease,
Most vertuous virgin borne of heauenly berth,
Then thou thy selfe, that was both borne and bred
For she is heauenly borne, and heauen may iustly vaunt.
Didst thou behight me borne of English blood,
Renew, as one were borne that very day.
He was an Elfin borne of noble state,
Ah lucklesse babe, borne vnder cruell starre,
Besought them by the womb, which them had borne,
And by her stately portance, borne of heauenly birth.
Seemes to be borne by natiue influence;
The which was borne of noble parentage,
Death is for wretches borne vnder vnhappie starre.
And borne of two faire Damsels, which were taught,
Mote deeme him borne with ill disposed skyes,
All were they borne of her owne natiue slime,
Borne of faire Inogene of Italy;
Which had seuen hundred yeares this scepter borne,
Whilest each of Brutus boasted to be borne,
The fierce Spumador borne of heauenly seed:
And noblest borne of all in Britayne land;
Or as the Cyprian goddesse, newly borne
And all sixe brethren, borne of one parent,
The noble Arthegall hath euer borne the name.
Yet is no Fary borne, ne sib at all
Be to the Briton babe, that shalbe borne,
There he this knight of her begot, whom borne
The wretched sonne of wretched mother borne,
To beene ybred and neuer borne to die?
Which he had borne of his bold enimee.
She heauenly borne, and of celestiall hew.
And all the Graces rockt her cradle being borne.
So was this virgin borne, so was she bred,
Had borne him, or his tract she mote detect:
Vnwares had borne two babes, as faire as springing day.
Of all things, that are borne to liue and die,
She with him liues, and hath him borne a chyld,
As if the wind him on his winges had borne,
Some of borne brethren, prov'd vnnaturall;
For she at first was borne of hellish brood,
Borne of one mother in one happie mold,
Borne at one burden in one happie morne;
And fruitfull apples to haue borne awhile,
And bright, that seemed borne of Angels brood,
And there made gods, though borne of mortall berth,
Sith to his powre we all are subiect borne:
They both her twins, both borne of heauenly seed,
Let then this plaint vnto his eares be borne,
That they haue crusht the Crab, and quite him borne
So he my loue away with him hath borne,
But Terpine borne to'a more vnhappy howre,
That they were borne to base humilitie,
Her dayes in warre, yet (weet thou) was not borne
To be so scorned of a base borne thrall,
And armes had borne, but little good could finde,
Borne vppon stately pillours, all dispred
Or vnder his fierce horses feet haue borne
She first was bred, and borne of heauenly race;
And sooth they say, that he was borne and bred
Borne of the brooding of Echidna base,
But ere that it she backe againe had borne,
That sure he deem'd him borne of noble race.
That sure he weend him borne of noble blood,
Or surely borne of some Heroicke sead,
Then wote ye that I am a Briton borne,
And borne great sway in armes amongst his peares:
The lusty Aladine, though meaner borne,
Me then to be full base and euill borne,
Mongst saluage beasts, both rudely borne and bred,
For certes he was borne of noble blood,
With so braue badges one so basely borne;
She was borne free, not bound to any wight,
And all his brethren borne in Britaine land;
Whence all that liues, does borrow life and light,
And borrow matter, whereof they are made,
And with extorted powre, and borrow'd strength,
And borrow'd beautie spoyld. Her nathelesse
He stroke so hugely with his borrowd blade,
Now haue three Moones with borrow'd brothers light,
Whose borrowed beautie now appeareth plaine
Of fowle Duessa, when her borrowed light
And her bright browes were deckt with borrowed haire:
To sell her borrowed beautie to abuse.
His borrowed waters forst to redisbourse,
That hast with borrowed plumes thy selfe endewed,
Is borrowed of them. But that faire one,
And in his bosome secretly there lay
Into great Tethys bosome, where they hidden lye.
Her bared bosome she doth broad display;
Out of their hollow bosome forth to throw
Vpgath'ring, in her bosome she comprized,
Where in her bosome she thee long had nurst,
And into her faire bosome made his grapes decline.
Great heapes of Salmons in his deepe bosome:
Into her pregnant bosome, forth she brought
There whilest in Morpheus bosome safe she lay,
Rent vp her brest, and bosome open layd,
Vppon the bosse with stones, that shined wide,
His deare Redeemers badge vpon the bosse:
Whose bridle rung with golden bels and bosses braue.
Yet knight was not for all his bragging bost,
That in aduauntage would his puissance bost:
Sith late with him I batteil vaine would boste;
As bosting in their martyrdome vnmeet.
Soone hearkned, and her painted bote streightway
